content: Is there any .net core open source FHIR Server implementation? I aware of .Net FHIR API available to build one. I had looked at Spark FHIR server http://spark.furore.com/, it doesn't seem to be working. I tried to post simple patient resource using Postman kept getting this error: InvalidOperationException: Mongo document contains invalid BSON to parse. Any feedback would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!
I think Spark is the only one - but it is old and it has been superseded by Vonk (that is no longer free / open source)
There is also https://github.com/Microsoft/fhir-server
But it is for Azure
You may want to take a look at https://pyrohealth.net/
I think Microsoft threw their hat in the ring, although Azure may be a requirement (I haven't tested this yet): https://github.com/Microsoft/fhir-server
Indeed -- this is an open-source .NET server designed to run on Azure!

Thank you @Michele Mottini for your input. I can't use Azure or other cloud for this. I want to host it locally.

Thanks you @Richard Kavanagh for referring me to this project. It is based on .net framework, not .net core. But something I can looking into more details.
@Matthew Koch @Josh Mandel Microsoft's FHIR server open source is integrated with Azure ecosystem using PaaS, Cosmos DB etc...

The error you are referring to for spark has been resolved in the last months after I took over the maintenance of the project. You would have to clone it from GitHub https://github.com/FirelyTeam/spark and set it up by yourself. The endpoint http://spark.furore.com probably is an older version of spark. Not yet a .Net Core version though.

@Matthew Koch @Josh Mandel Microsoft's FHIR server open source is integrated with Azure ecosystem using PaaS, Cosmos DB etc...

Our Dev team uses the cosmos emulator for testing, etc. on local machines. It is not something I would recommend for production use, but it works. Did you have problems with it?

Curious if any of the team at Furore or other .NET guys like @Brian Postlethwaite have looked at Microsoft's FHIR server for Azure. FWIW, my group implemented a FHIR server on Azure two years ago, before Cosmos was available.
I have had a very quick look, but not detailed enough to make any real comment on it. (not even sure it if only supports the Azure CosmosDB - which can be quite pricy)
